claim: Americans earn less  than people in certain countries.

supporting.text: The median household income in the United States is lower than that of countries like Switzerland and Norway.

attacks.text: The median household income in the United States is lower than that of countries like Switzerland and Norway.
Median income comparisons can be misleading due to differences in cost of living; purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show the U.S. performs better.
Even after PPP adjustments, certain essential goods and services (e.g., healthcare, education) remain significantly more expensive in the U.S., offsetting income advantages.
The U.S. has higher income inequality, so median income underrepresents earnings for many middle-class Americans compared to more egalitarian countries like Norway.
Norway's wealth equality is partly due to its small, homogeneous population and oil reserves—factors not replicable in larger, diverse economies like the U.S.

supporting.text: Countries with higher GDP per capita, such as Luxembourg and Ireland, have higher average earnings than the United States.

attacks.text: Countries with higher GDP per capita, such as Luxembourg and Ireland, have higher average earnings than the United States.
GDP per capita does not directly reflect median earnings due to income inequality; some countries may have high GDP per capita but uneven wealth distribution.
Even with income inequality, countries like Luxembourg and Ireland consistently report higher median incomes than the U.S., supporting A2's claim.
Cost of living in high-GDP-per-capita countries is often much higher, reducing real earnings compared to nominal figures.
Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments confirm that real earnings in these countries still exceed U.S. levels in many cases.

supporting.text: Certain European nations with strong social welfare systems, like Denmark and Sweden, report higher average wages than the U.S.

attacks.text: Certain European nations with strong social welfare systems, like Denmark and Sweden, report higher average wages than the U.S.
The cost of living in Denmark and Sweden is significantly higher than in the U.S., which offsets their higher nominal wages.
Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) adjustments show that real wages in the U.S. are competitive or superior to those in Denmark and Sweden when accounting for cost of living.
The U.S. has a much larger income inequality gap, so median wages may be a better comparison than average wages.
Even when using median wages, certain high-tax European countries still outperform the U.S. due to more equitable wage distribution policies.

supporting.text: The U.S. has a wider income inequality gap compared to some developed nations, leading to lower median earnings relative to their top earners.

attacks.text: The U.S. has a wider income inequality gap compared to some developed nations, leading to lower median earnings relative to their top earners.
Median household income in the U.S. is higher than in most developed countries when adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).
PPP adjustments may not fully account for cost-of-living disparities in healthcare and education, which are higher in the U.S.
Income inequality does not necessarily correlate with median earnings; some high-inequality countries still have high median incomes.
Wider income inequality often suppresses median earnings due to disproportionate wealth concentration at the top.

supporting.text: Countries with progressive taxation and labor policies, such as Germany and the Netherlands, often have higher take-home pay for middle-class workers than Americans.

attacks.text: Countries with progressive taxation and labor policies, such as Germany and the Netherlands, often have higher take-home pay for middle-class workers than Americans.
The cost of living in countries like Germany and the Netherlands is significantly higher than in many parts of the U.S., offsetting the higher take-home pay.
Even accounting for cost of living differences, purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show that middle-class workers in these countries still have greater disposable income.
The U.S. has a wider range of salaries across industries, with tech and finance sectors offering much higher earnings than comparable roles in Europe.
While some high-earning sectors in the U.S. pay more, these opportunities are concentrated in specific regions and require specialized skills, leaving many middle-class workers behind.
